original_data.question:
A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He reports that one hour ago he was climbing the stairs in his home when he suddenly developed excruciating chest pain. He describes the pain as ripping and radiating to the back. The patient’s past medical history is significant for a heart murmur that is being followed by his outpatient cardiologist. He takes no medications. The patient works as a carpenter and reports being monogamous with his wife. He denies any history of intravenous drug use or recent travel. In the emergency department, the patient’s temperature is 99.4°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 94/56 mmHg, pulse is 121/min, and respirations are 14/min. On physical exam, the patient appears to be in moderate distress and is clutching his chest. He is tall and has joint hypermobility. His breath sounds are equal and full bilaterally and has weak distal pulses.

Which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient?

options.A: Holosystolic, high-pitched blowing murmur at the lower left sternal border
options.B: Late systolic crescendo murmur at the apex with mid-systolic click
options.C: Mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border
options.D: Systolic ejection murmur at the right second intercostal space

model_response:
The patient’s clinical presentation is consistent with acute aortic regurgitation. The most likely cause of acute aortic regurgitation in a young, otherwise healthy individual is aortic root dilation or aortic dissection. The murmur associated with aortic regurgitation is a high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo murmur heard at the left lower sternal border. The murmur of aortic regurgitation is different from the murmur of aortic stenosis. The murmur of aortic stenosis is an ejection systolic murmur that is harsh sounding and is best heard at the right second intercostal space. A late systolic crescendo murmur with mid-systolic click is characteristic of mitral valve prolapse. A mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border is characteristic of aortic stenosis.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Pressure, burning, or numbness in the chest.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
Intensely painful.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
A removal done by peeling, often using a stripper
The rear surface of an upright primate from the shoulders to the hip, or the dorsal surface of tetrapods.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

Heart sounds caused by vibrations resulting from the flow of blood through the heart. Heart murmurs can be examined by HEART AUSCULTATION, and analyzed by their intensity (6 grades), duration, timing (systolic, diastolic, or continuous), location, transmission, and quality (musical, vibratory, blowing, etc).
Qualified medical professionals who specialize in preventing and treating disorders of the heart and CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
Record and study of past events.
MOVEMENT across different GEOGRAPHIC LOCATIONS.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A state of physiological or psychological stress that cannot be compensated for by normal adaptive measures.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
Looseness or instability of a joint.
Noises, normal and abnormal, heard on auscultation over any part of the RESPIRATORY TRACT.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
Having strength, power, or intensity less than average or expected.
